Armen is 28 years old. He lives in Bolnisi district with his parents. Armen requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of his low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

Armen has a grocery shop and he earns small daily income for the family. He also trades fruits and vegetables. His mother has a health problems and she is getting a monthly pension from government institutions. 

Armen requested loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Armen has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit Armen will open a car service center. He will purchase all the needed materials to build the center and also the equipment for it. Armen is a car artisan and wants to start his new business. As he is well known among the villagers he will have good numbers of clients and earn additional income for the family.  The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To open a car service center.

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is a married woman with six children all under her care. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Dama runs a vegetable and fruit-selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit vendor in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason, with the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges and mangoes,. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges and mangoes.

loans.name: New Africa Group

texts.en:
Tunu, who is in her early 50s, is married with six children and all of them go to school. She has been running a business selling dry food like sugar, beans, baking flour, wheat flour, salt etc for six years now.  She works from 9.00 am to 4.00 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Tunu's fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to restock the items which were out of stock, started selling clothes door-to-door and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She used the profit to pay school fees, bought a plot of land, started building her house and covered household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy more rice, beans, sugar, flour, salt and to buy more clothes to sell door-to-door. Her dream is to one day be able to finish building her house.

Tunu will share this loan with her loan group "New Africa" with eleven members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more rice, beans, sugar, flour, salt and to buy more clothes to sell door-to-door.

loans.name: Halfan

texts.en:
This is Halfan. His previous loan was a big help in his business. He was able to purchase sacks of onions, tomatoes, and fruit. He has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing. 

He would like to apply for another loan, this time for KES 20,000, to improve his fish-selling business, to purchase a fishing boat. His profits from business will definitely help him to sustain his daily needs and the educational expenses of his children. He looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in his heart.

loans.use: to purchase a fishing boat.

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka is a 44-year-old married mother with three children; the eldest is ten and the youngest three. She describes herself as a confident and determined mother. She is applying for a KES 10,000 loan through SMEP DTM that she will use to purchase kale, onions and potatoes as stock. Her major challenge is transport costs but she can see herself in the near future having a chain of grocery stores. The profits made from the business will be used to enhance her family's welfare. This is her first application for a loan. 

SMEP is a Deposit Taking Microfinance institution born out of an initiative of the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK). It began as a feeding programme to feed the Mathare slum dwellers in Nairobi, Kenya. NCCK realized that the poor needed to be self-reliant and economically empowered and the feeding programme was transformed into a micro-credit scheme. What started as a small project has grown into a deposit taking micro-finance institution that has a dream of providing many financial solutions to entrepreneurs. In future, SMEP plans to become a fully fledged Christian bank.

loans.use: To purchase kale, onions and potatoes as stock.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda tiene 37 años y esta casada con Manuel de 45 años , tiene una casa hecha de madera donde vive con sus 5 hijos dos de los cuales ya son personas mayores e independientes. Hilda se dedica a la venta de desayunos en un carrito que acoplo para realizar su negocio.Anteriormente solo dependía económicamente de su esposo porque ella cuidaba de sus menores hijos, pero cuando crecieron decidió trabajar para mejorar su economía familiar.
Uso el dinero que había ahorrado junto a su esposo para la compra de su carrito  sanguchero el cual estaciona en la puerta de la escuela local y ofrece a sus clientes quienes son alumnos y profesores , ofrece diversa variedad de bebidas preparadas a base de quinua, maca y soya así como los deliciosos panes que rellena con palta, queso, jamón ,entre otros.Todos los días se despierta muy temprano para la preparación de los alimentos porque le gusta ofrecer a su clientela productos frescos y de buena calidad además del buen sabor.Trabaja siempre pensando en el futuro de su familia y su principal objetivo a largo plazo es obtener dinero suficiente para construir su vivienda a base de material noble y mejorar su calidad de vida, se siente segura de cumplirlo ya que sus hijos son su principal motivación para seguir adelante.Este es su primer préstamo otorgado por Kiva motivo por el cual agradece la confianza brindada esperando invertir en la mejora de su negocio y cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de manera puntual.En esta oportunidad requiere 1,000 soles para comprar insumos al por mayor tales como papas nativas, paltas , queso fresco , entre otros ,los cuales obtiene en el mercado central.
texts.en:
Hilda is 37 years old and married to Manuel, who is 45.  Her house is made from wood and she lives there with her five children, two of whom are already adults and independent.  Hilda's business is selling breakfasts from a cart.  In the past, she was financially dependent on her husband as her job was caring for their children.  However, as the children grew up, she decided to work outside the home in order to improve the family's financial situation.

Hilda used some money that she and her husband had saved up to buy her fast-food cart which she sets up outside the local school and sells to her customers who are students and teachers.  She offers a wide range of quinoa-, maca root- and soy-based drinks as well as delicious bread filled with avocado, queso fresco (a soft, mild cheese), ham, etc.  Every day, Hilda wakes up very early so that she can prepare her food.  She does this because she likes offering her customers good-quality, fresh, good-tasting food.  She always thinks of her family's future as she works and her main long-term goals are to make enough money to re-build their home from solid building materials and to improve their quality of life.  She feels certain that she will achieve this as her children are her main motivation to keep going.

This is Hilda's first loan through Kiva and she is grateful for the trust that is being placed in her.  She hopes to invest in improving her business and to make each of her monthly repayments on time.  On this occasion, she needs 1,000 soles to buy supplies wholesale such as potatoes, avocados, queso fresco, etc.  She obtains these supplies in the central market.

loans.use: to buy potatoes, avocados, queso fresco, etc.

loans.name: Mwashamba

texts.en:
For the past years, Mwashamba has owned a retail shop business, where neighbours and town dwellers are her potential customers. She faces a major challenge of fluctuations in the number of clients hence some of her goods perish, leading to losses.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour and cooking fat. She dreams of expanding her business into a modern café. She appreciates the previous Kiva loan and the support.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of goods like sugar, rice, maize and wheat flour and cooking fat.

loans.name: Hantma Group

texts.en:
This group is called Hantma and consists of three ladies who live in Aden, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 180,000 YER from AMB. 

Khamisa is a 53-year-old married woman and a mother of six children. She started a small business selling potatoes, flour and other food many years ago. She found it difficult to accumulate a large amount of money to expand her business because most of the profit she makes goes on her family expenses including clothes and food. Therefore, she decided to apply for a loan of 60,000 YER to buy many packs of flour to use in her business to increase her daily income. 

She looks forward to opening a retail shop which in turn will result in her improving her income and increasing her income above the poverty line.

loans.use: to buy many packs of flour to use in her business to increase her daily income.

loans.name: Hang

texts.en:
Hang was born in 1977. She has two children who are learning at high-school and primary school. Her husband is a farmer. He earns about 3,000,000 VND per month. Hang grows rice and sells vegetables to earn a living. Her income is about 3,000,000 VND. She has done this job for 10 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 6,000,000 VND per month. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2003. In the last cycle she borrowed 9,810,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 11,118,000 VND to grow and sell vegetables. She wants to raise her children well.

loans.use: to grow and sell vegetables.

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon repayed his previous loan and the transport business is doing well. He managed to open  a spare parts shop. This marks Simon's third loan from KADET LTD to buy more spares parts for sale. He has done great, and has been able to service his loans successfully. He hopes to prosper in his new business and the transport one.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for sale.

loans.name: Caro

texts.en: Caro is appreciative of the previous Kiva loan which helped her to boost her business. She is requesting another loan of Kshs 50,000 to buy more rice, beans, soft drinks, cooking fat, wheat four and maize flour to sell as her business has expanded. She now has many more clients than before. Caro is thankful for Yehu and Kiva support.

loans.use: to buy more rice, beans, soft drinks, cooking fat, wheat four and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 33-year-old Hawa from Torkpoi town, Bo. She is married with two children aged two and seven. One of her children is attending school. 

Hawa runs a palm oil business; she sells gallons of palm oil. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business 7 hours per day and 6 days per week. Hawa says that the main challenges to her business are the poor road network and that sometimes the vehicle breaks down on the way.

Hawa has requested a loan in order to purchase more gallon of palm oil for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to take care of her family and pay school fees for her child. In the future, she plans to open a big palm oil store. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase more gallons of palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Hoa's Group

texts.en:
Hoa was born in 1969. She has two daughters and a son. Her oldest daughter is learning at a vocational school. Her older child is learning at high-school. Her son is learning at kindergarten. Her husband is a construction worker and earns about 4,000,000 VND per month. Hoa is a farmer to earn a living. Her income is about 3,000,000 VND. She has done this job for 20 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2013. In this first loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy peach seeds to plant flowering peach trees.  

The other member who is part of Hoa's group is Lan who is 36 years old. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND to plant flowering peach trees

loans.use: to buy peach seeds to plant flowering peach trees.

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roseline is a 51-year-old married mother with five children. She describes herself as an ambitious mother and is keen to support her family and improve their living conditions. She is applying for a KES 30,000 loan which she will use to purchase bananas and kale as stock. Her challenge is inadequate funds to stock her business and she describes her field of activity as competitive. 

This is her first loan application through SMEP DTM. SMEP is a Deposit Taking Microfinance institution born out of an initiative of the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK). It began as a feeding programme to feed the Mathare slum dwellers in Nairobi, Kenya. NCCK realized that the poor needed to be self reliant and economically empowered and the feeding programme was transformed into a micro-credit scheme. What started as a small project has grown into a deposit taking micro-finance institution that has a dream of providing many financial solutions to entrepreneurs. In future, SMEP plans to become a fully fledged Christian bank.

loans.use: To purchase bananas and kale as stock.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema lives in Malindi area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is married and has six school-going children. Neema owns a food stall, a business which she has been operating for two years. This is her only source of income currently.

She learne about Milango through friends who invited her to the group and she joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main challenges are competition and the high costs of transport while sourcing for the goods, but she believes she can reduce this by purchasing large quantities through this loan. 

Neema is applying for a loan of 31,500 Kenya shillings to buy food stock like flour, cooking fat, rice, fuel wood etc. She will use the extra from the loan to improve on the living standards of her family, and especially education.

loans.use: To buy food stock like flour, cooking fat, rice, fuel wood etc.

loans.name: Mwanapili

texts.en:
Mwanapili is married and she supports her family financially. They live in their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a food stall business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces major challenges such as seasonality and competition from other food stall operators in her business. 

With KES 30,000 she wants to buy more products like rice, sugar, milk, bread and maize flour to sell. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to buy more products like rice, sugar, milk, bread and maize flour to sell.

loans.name: Janefer's Group

texts.en:
Janefer's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Janefer is 22 years old and lives in the town of Wobulezi in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past two years, Janefer has been working hard to manage her salon, which does hair dressing. 

To help expand her business, Janefer has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy and start selling second-hand clothes, and will help Janefer to generate greater profits and bring electricity to her house. Janefer hopes that in the future she will be able to build rental houses. 

Janefer is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy and start selling second-hand clothes.

loans.name: Nha

texts.en:
Nha was born in 1975. She has two children who are studying at high-school and primary school. Her husband is a constructional worker. He earns about 4,000,000 VND per month. Nha grows rice and raises bees to earn a living. Her income is about 3,000,000 VND. She has done this job for 15 years. Her family’s total earnings are about 7,000,000 VND per month. 

She has participated in SEDA's credit program since 2003. In the last cycle she borrowed 8,938,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 10,246,000 VND to raise bees and to sell honey. She wants to raise her children well and complete her house construction.

loans.use: to raise bees and to sell honey.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary lives in the Malindi area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is married and has seven school-going children. She owns a grocery store that has been running for twenty years. She is also employed and sells charcoal. She learned about Milango through friends, who invited her to the group, and she joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main challenges are competition and food perishability. Mary is applying for a loan of 21,000 KES (Kenya shillings) to buy stock, such as fruits, vegetables, maize, beans, rice, cooking fat and charcoal, to sell. The extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to improve the living standard of her family and pay school fees for her children. She aspires to open a mini-wholesale store.

loans.use: to buy stock for her grocery store, such as maize, beans, rice, cooking fat and charcoal.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en: For some years, Mwanaisha has operated an open-air food stall business; her potential customers are market workers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuations of products in the market. She is applying for a new loan of KES 40,000 to buy sacks of beans, cooking oil, wheat flour and rice to sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business, and she greatly appreciates the help.

loans.use: to buy sacks of beans, cooking oil, wheat flour and rice to sell in her open-air stall.

loans.name: Nyabwana

texts.en: Nyabwana is a 53-year-old divorced woman. She has seven children, with ages ranging from 12 to 31. She describes herself as being committed. She operates a beauty products and dress-making stall, where she sells beauty products and dresses. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in an area with many customers, and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge as infrastructure delays. She will use the KES 60,000 loan to buy a supply of beauty products. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years. She hopes that, in the future, she will have improved her living standards. This is her fifth loan from SMEP DTM. Her previous loans were paid successfully.

loans.use: to buy a stock of beauty products to sell.

loans.name: Bidii

texts.en: Bidii is a resident of Malindi, Kenya. He is a single businessman and runs a curio shop selling handmade embroidery. The business has been in operation for five years. He was introduced to Milango by his friends and joined to access credit for business expansion. Bidii is asking for a loan of 21,100 KES (Kenya shillings) to buy shoe soles, leather and beads to make shoes and embroidered artifacts. He believes the income generated as a result of receiving this loan will help improve his lifestyle and enable him plan for the future.

loans.use: to buy shoe soles, leather and beads to make shoes and embroidered artifacts to sell in his curio shop.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a married man with a child. He describes himself as an honest father who wants to give his child a better future.

He has been in business for 3 years and would like to apply for a loan of 50,000 KES through SMEP DTM, which he will use to purchase chemical products for his salon. He describes his customers as his local residents. He would like to build a permanent place for his family using the profits made. 

SMEP is a Deposit Taking Microfinance institution born out of an initiative of the National Council of Churches of Kenya (NCCK). It began as a feeding program to feed the Mathare slum dwellers in Nairobi, Kenya. NCCK realized that the poor needed to be self reliant and economically empowered and the feeding program was transformed into a microcredit scheme. What started as a small project has grown into a deposit taking microfinance institution that has a dream of providing many financial solutions to entrepreneurs. In future, SMEP plans to become a fully fledged Christian bank.

loans.use: to purchase chemical products for his salon

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en:
This is 34-year-old Memunatu from Torkpoi town Bo. She is married with 2 children between the ages of 1 and 7 years.

Menunatu runs a palm oil business in her area.  She sells palm oil and gari (cassava flakes). She has been running this business for 9 years. She works at the business every day from morning to night. She says that the main challenges to her business are a poor road network within her operation area.   

Memunatu has requested a loan in order to buy more gallons of palm oil and gari. The extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her level of living. In the future, she plans to have a permanent residence for her family. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy more gallons of palm oil and gari

loans.name: Lan's Group

texts.en: Lan was born in 1965. She has two children. Her son is a worker and her daughter is in high school. Her husband is a building worker, and his income is about 4,000,000 VND. She is a farmer, as she has been for 20 years. She earns 3,000,000 VND a month. The total earnings of her family are about 7,000,000 VND per month. She has taken part in SEDA's loan program since 2012. In her last loan cycle, Lan borrowed 5,014,000 VND and repaid the loan on time. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy more seeds and plant flowering peach trees. She wants to improve her family's living standards. The other member of Lan's Group is Huong, 38 years old, who wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND to plant a peach tree.

loans.use: to buy more seeds and plant flowering peach trees.

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama lives in the Malindi area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is married and has four children. She owns a greengrocery, a business which she has been operating for over ten years. She sells tomatoes, sugar, onions, etc., in this business. Dama also sells charcoal.

She learned about Milango through friends who invited her to the group and she joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main challenge is food spoilage.

Dama is applying for a loan of 21,100 Kenyan shillings to buy vegetables and fruits at wholesale for resale. Her extra income from the loan will be added to her savings to construct a rental house and improve on the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and fruits at wholesale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees for the kids.

She has operated a cosmetic selling shop business, selling at retail to her clients. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in her business.

With the loan that she is requesting of 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase stock of cosmetics like necklaces, bangles, body lotions and earrings. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of cosmetics like necklaces, bangles, body lotions and earrings

loans.name: Zuena

texts.en:
Zuena is a married mother of three children, all of whom attend school.  She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and transport.

For the past three years, Zuena has operated a clothes business, selling door to door to her neighbors and passersby.  She faces a major challenge of transportation of her goods.  She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that Zuena is requesting of Kes 20,000 to purchase bales of clothes for resale.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ayoub

texts.en:
Ayoub is Ugandan, aged 55 and married to Jackline.  They have 10 children ages 27, 25, 23, 21, 19, 17, 15, 13 and 9.  Five attend school.  The family also has a house keeper who is a dependent.

Ayoub has a retail shop business where he sells beans, soap, rice, maize and other items.  He serves clients who live around his neighborhood, and he operates his shop six days a week, 13hours daily.  Ayoub started his business in 1992.  He generates additional income through agriculture, mainly maize, and through rentals.

Ayoub wants a loan of 1,500,000 to buy more items like sugar and salt to resell.  His dream is to expand his shop, however he faces a challenge of  competition.

He is honest and shrewd in business and would like to thank the lenders.

loans.use: to buy more items like sugar and  salt.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 35-year-old Fatmata from Torkpoi town in Bo.  She is married with 2 children between the ages of 12 years and 18 years.  Fatmata's children attend school. She began her business because she wants to stop sitting at home as a house wife and create a permanent source of income to take care of her needs. 

Fatmata runs a general stock business. She sells clothes, suit cases and food containers.  She has been running this business for the past 5 years.  Fatmata works 8 hours per day and 7 days per week.

Fatmata has requested a loan to buy more clothes, suit cases and food containers.  The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her life and her family's well being.  In the future, she plans to open a big general store.  She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more clothes, suit cases and food containers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Mwanamkuu

texts.en:
Mwanamkuu is a married mother.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family.

For the past two years, she has operated a food café, selling from home to passersby and neighbors.  She dreams of establishing a restaurant shop in the future.

With the loan she wants to purchase bundles of sugar, cooking oil, potatoes, wheat flour and maize flour.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of sugar, cooking oil, potatoes, wheat flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Protea Group

texts.en:
Mwanamvua, who is in her late 40's is married with five children who attend school.  She has been selling cassava flour for three years.  She works from 7.00 am to 4.00 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Mwanamvua's 13th loans from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to buy bags for packing cassava flour, paid the packing machine expenses and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She used the profit to pay school fees, continued building her house and covered household expenses. 

Mwanamvua will use this loan to buy more cassava to make more cassava flour to sell to more customers.  Her dream is to finish building her house.

Mwanamvua will share this loan with her loan group "PROTEA," with ten members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more cassavs.

loans.name: Lisbon Group

texts.en:
Salumu, who is in his mid 20s, is married with one small child. He has been a decorator for four years now. He works from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.
 
This will be Salumu's 7th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to buy normal decorative materials and decorative lights and small items for his business and he has paid back all of his loans successfully. He used the profits to buy land and to cover household expenses. He will use this loan to buy more advanced decorative materials and more advanced decorative lights. His dream is to one day be able to buy more materials and tables.

Salumu will share this loan with his loan group "Lisbon" with nine members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more advanced decorative materials and more advanced decorative lights.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 27 years old and married with two children, ages 1 and 6 years old. Her husband is an old man retired from his job; she always takes care of the home by herself. She runs a provision store in Torkpoi town, Bo, Southern Area in Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business for seven years and sells milk, butter, sugar and bread. She says that her business is run well because, out of the profit, she is able to take care of the home.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase palm oil and provision items to expand her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like to educate her children. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil and provision items to expand her business.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 26-year-old married man and a father of a child who lives in Sana`a, Yemen. He is employed and gets a low salary, which is the only source of income for the family and not quite enough to cover all their needs.

He is requesting a youth loan of 150,000 YER from AMB to help him cover the cost of purchasing new bedroom furniture in order to improve the living conditions in his house. Taking out this loan will offer his family comfortable and suitable furniture so they can enjoy living in their house.

loans.use: to help him cover the cost of purchasing new bedroom furniture

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is a 30-year-old married mother of two who is applying for a loan of Kes 20,000 which will be used to purchase material for her business. She has been in this trade for three years This is her first loan through SMEP DTM. She has been a saleslady at a restaurant in Mombasa.

loans.use: To purchase material for her business

loans.name: Maria Aquilina

texts.es: Doña Maria de 59 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo, sus tres hijos y su nieto, ella tiene un negocio de venta de tortillas desde hace varios años, trabaja de lunes a domingo tiene mucha clientela pues es una persona muy trabajadora y amable, con las ganancias que obtiene de sus ventas logra salir adelante con su familia. Doña maria solicita un credito para poder comprar maiz y gas para seguir con su negocio y asi darle a su familia lo que necesita sin limitacion alguna.
texts.en:
María, 59, lives in her own house with her husband, three children, and grandchild.

She has had a business selling tortillas for several years and works from Monday through Sunday.  She has a lot of customers because she's a very hardworking and friendly person.  With her profits from her sales she's able to get ahead with her family.

María's requesting a loan to be able to buy corn and gas to continue with her business and give her family what they need without any limitations.

loans.use: to buy corn to make tortillas

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
Dickson is a 41-year-old married man. He has one child aged 12 years. He describes himself to be very ambitious. He operates a car hire business where he rents cars to customers at a fee. He has been involved in this business for eight years. His business is located in an area with many customers and his primary customers are clients from offices and also business people. 

Dickson describes his biggest business challenge to be lack of clients. He will use the Kes 50,000 loan to to buy spare parts for his cars and also fuel for them. His business goal is to own a fleet of cars within five years. He hopes that in the future, his business will grow. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his cars and also fuel for them

loans.name: Hannington

texts.en: Hannington is a 28-year-old man who is applying for a 50,000 KES loan through SMEP DTM which he will use to purchase second hand beds for his stock. He describes himself as ambitious. He is operating in an open market where he has been operating his business for 2 years. A challenge he faces is inadequate stock for his customers.

loans.use: To purchase second-hand beds for his stock.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 44-year-old married woman. She has 3 children with ages ranging from 6 to 19 years. She describes herself as very ambitious. She operates a clothing retail store where she sells used clothes to customers. She has been involved in this business for 5 years. Her business is located in an area with many customers and her primary customers are children, men and ladies. Jane describes a lack of funds as her biggest business challenge.

She will use the 30,000 KES loan to to buy more stock of clothes to sell. Her business goal is to own a boutique within 5 years. She hopes that in the future she will improve her standard of living. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. The previous loan was paid successfully. Jane will use the anticipated profits to pay the loan and bills.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Cyrus

texts.en:
Cyrus is 48 years old, married, and a father of ten children. For the last twenty years, he has earned a living by selling farm produce in Mpeketoni, Lamu. He earns a monthly profit of 8,000 KES. 

Cyrus was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer, and is applying for his third loan of 25,000 KES to buy seeds, some fertilizer and other farm inputs needed for his business. 

He will use the profits made possible by this loan to pay school fees for his children as well as to expand his farming activities. His goal for the future is to venture into mixed farming with a view of increasing his income so as to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: To purchse farm inputs for his farming activities.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Ms. Nasreen is 45 years old and works from home as a tailor. She has been in this line of work for 12 years now and is proud to be contributing to her household income. When Nasreen was not earning, her family was going through a severe financial crisis that compelled her to use her stitching skills in a productive manner. Her husband was the sole breadwinner of the family, and due to limited resources, none of her three daughters were sent to school. Nasreen felt it obligatory to change her family’s living standards and started working from home. 

She had established a good clientele but was having difficulty in fulfilling large orders. That’s when her neighbor advised her to borrow from Kashf. She is in her sixth loan cycle; currently she requested a loan of Rs 10,000 and her loan will be used to purchase a new stitching machine, with some spools of thread in various colors.

loans.use: to purchase a new stitching machine, with some spools of thread in various colors.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a married man with 5 children. He describes himself as an open minded father who wants to provide for his children. He is applying for a loan of 20,000 KES which he will use to purchase beverages, flour, kale and cakes for his restaurant.He says that the business is located in a marketable area. The anticipated profits will be used to expand his business and cater to his family's needs.

loans.use: to purchase beverages, flour, kale and cakes for his restaurant.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Meet 32-year-old Hawa from Kandeh town, Southern area in Sierra Leone. She is married with three children between the ages of two years and 12 years. Two of her children are currently attending school. In 2003, Hawa established her bar business. She began her business because she was trained in this business. She works at the business throughout the week. She says that her business is doing well by having more customers. 

Hawa requires a loan in order to buy a variety of drinks like sodas, stout and beer. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her family's living conditions from poverty to riches. In the future, Hawa plans to see her business grow and develop to standard level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy a variety of drinks like sodas, stout and beer.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a married woman. She has two children, ages 18 months and 10 years. She describes herself as very ambitious. She operates a beauty salon where she does weaving, braiding and relaxing of hair. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in an area with many customers and her primary customers are ladies and schoolgirls. She describes her biggest business challenge as insufficient funds. She will use this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan to purchase a hair dryer. Her business goal is to open another beauty salon within five years. She also hopes to open a beauty school in the future. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to purchase a hair dryer

loans.name: Rusiana

texts.en:
Rusiana is a widow who lives in Voi. She sells food, helped by her family.She lives in a rental house with electricity but no piped water.She runs a food stall to earn a living and support her extended family.

She always struggles to improve her food stall, trying to sell more and save money in order to have a more formal establishment. She is requesting a loan of Kes 50,000 to buy beans, sugar, oil, vegetables, beef, chicken, and food packaging.

loans.use: to buy beans, sugar, oil, vegetables, beef, chicken, and food packaging.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 22 years old and lives in the town of Luwero in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past two years, Rose has been working hard to manage her small soft drink business. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more soft drinks such as soda, water and juice to sell, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her family. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to own land and build rental houses. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks such as soda, water and juice to sell

loans.name: Samina

texts.en:
Ms. Samina is a 36-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband at the corner of her house. She has gained two years of experience in this field.  By this time she has become known in her community and people prefer to shop at her store on a daily basis. 

Samina is the best earning resource in her household. She is a mother of four children and is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing and health. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of Rs. 15,000 to buy packs of salt, biscuits and beverages to meet with the increasing demand at her store. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of providing quality education to her children through all her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to buy packs of salt, biscuits and beverages to meet with the increasing demand at her store.

loans.name: Kaniz

texts.en:
Ms. Kaniz is a 37-year-old married woman; she has been in the business of selling milk for the past eight years. She has two buffalo and three cows in milk. She sells their milk to many of her neighbors, along with butter that she makes from the milk. Her business is good enough to allow her to lead a decent life. She has   two sons and three daughters. She is very motivated to provide them a beautiful life with good food, health and clothing. 

Kaniz has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation.  It’s her third loan cycle; she is happily running her business through support of it. Currently she requested a loan of Rs 35,000 to purchase one more cow. She is hopeful to get an increase in her earnings and dreams to expand her business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow.

loans.name: Fozia

texts.en:
Ms. Fozia is a 29-year-old married woman doing a business of selling milk for the past two years. She has three buffaloes and two cows in milk. She sells their milk to many of her neighbors, along with butter that she makes from the milk. Her business is good enough to allow her to lead a decent life. She has one son, so she is very motivated to provide her family with a beautiful life. 

Fozia has improved her business to meet the day-to-day expenses of life. She has some savings put aside and applied for a loan of Rs. 25,000 to purchase another cow. She hopes to get increase in her net income by catering for more people in her community.

loans.use: to purchase another cow.

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella is a married woman with one child who still attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water.

She has operated a grocery shop for the past year, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces the major challenge of debtors taking too long to pay her. 

With this loan, she she wants to purchase stocks of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Ms Sakina is a 44-year-old married woman. The man shown in the photo is Sakina’s husband; he started a small general store at the corner of her house five months ago. His business is good enough to meet the family expenses, but now he needs to purchase more things for his shop and extend his business. For this reason, Sakina contacted Kashf Foundation and applied a loan of 25,000 PKR. In this way her, husband will be able to purchase stocks of grains, oil, and packs of cleaning products such as soaps and detergents. Sakina is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of grains, oil, and packs of cleaning products such as soaps and detergents.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 16 years old and lives in the town of Luwero in the Luwero region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells vegetables. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 200000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy fruits like mangoes and bananas to sell, helping Sarah generate greater profits and providing for the basic needs for her family. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to build her own residential house. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy fruits like mangoes and bananas to sell,

loans.name: Muzammil

texts.en: Muzammil, 26, is a married, hardworking lady. She decided to work with her husband to support her family for a better future. The man shown in the photo is Muzammil’s husband. Two years ago, they began sewing shoes in her house. They receive orders from the shoe factory and make enough to meet the needs of their children. In order to complete the orders on time, they need to purchase more spools of threads, packs of needles and leather material. For this reason, Muzammil applied a loan of 20,000 PKR from the Kashf Foundation. In this way, she can handle the growing demand of her shoes in the market and better support her family.

loans.use: to purchase more spools of threads, packs of needles and leather material.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 48 years old and married with three children. She sells local foodstuffs in Torkpoi town, Southern Area, in Sierra Leone. She's been in this business for 15 years and sells palm oil, beans and plantain. She says that the main challenge to her business is at times in the vehicle her goods get spoiled on the way.

Susan requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to buy different kinds of local commodities like palm oil, beans, plantain and gari. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and educate her children. In the future, she would like a permanent business location. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to buy different kinds of local commodities like palm oil, beans, plantain and gari.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Ms. Asia is a 40-year-old married woman doing a business of selling milk for the past one year. She has one buffalo in milk. She sells its milk to many of her neighbors, along with butter that she makes from the milk. Her business is good enough to allow her to lead a decent life. She has four children.. She is very motivated to provide them a beautiful life with good education, food and clothing.  

Asia has improved her business to meet the day-to-day expenses of life.  It’s her third year with Kashf Foundation; she is happily running her business through support of it. Now she requested a loan of Rs 40,000 to purchase one more cow and feed for its calves. She hopes to have an increase in the production capacity of milk which ultimately helps in generating more cash.

loans.use: to purchase one more cow and feed for its calves.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: Godfrey is a 33-year-old married man. He has 3 children with ages ranging from 8 to 13 years. He describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a pharmacy where he sells medicine. His business is located in an area with many customers and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge as a lack of funds. He will use the 20,000 KES loan to to buy more medicine to sell. His business goal is to expand the business within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will excel in his business. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM. He will use the anticipated profits to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy more medicine to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy zinc sheets and pay for purlins, and pay for labor.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman. She has two children, ages 5 and 16 years. She describes herself as very focused. She operates a beauty shop where she does weaving, braiding and relaxing of hair. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in an area with many customers and her primary customers are ladies and schoolgirls. She describes her biggest business challenge as insufficient funds. She will use this 20,000 Kenyan shilling loan to purchase hair relaxers and hair weaves. Her business goal is to open another beauty shop within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to purchase hair relaxers and hair weaves

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
This is 38-year-old Fatmata from Torkpoi town, Southern Area, in Sierra Leone. She is married with three children between the ages of 12 and 17 years old.

Fatmata runs a cookery business; she sells cookery at home. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business 12 hours per day and 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is sometimes the price of goods in the market is very expensive.

Fatmata has requested a loan in order to buy rice, palm oil, onions and fish. The extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and help her pay her children's school fees. In the future, she hopes and prays to expand her business to a restaurant level. She appreciates your support.

loans.use: to buy rice, palm oil, onions and fish.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Although she has received no formal education, Ernestina is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling groceries in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). She has been involved in this enterprise for four years. Ernestina is married and has six children. Her husband is retired. 

As the sole breadwinner in the family, the proceeds from Ernestina's business normally go towards covering the entire family’s general expenses. 

Ernestina wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of groceries. In the long term, Ernestina plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels of groceries

loans.name: Zaton

texts.en:
Ms. Zaton is a 33-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband at the corner of her house. The man shown in the photo is Zaton’s husband. She has gained 10 years of experience in this field.  Her husband is good at dealing with customers and also assists her by purchasing goods from the market at wholesale rates. Zaton is a mother of two children and is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing and health. She has gradually improved her business with the support of Kashf Foundation. 

Currently, she requested a loan of Rs. 30,000 to buy packs of salt, biscuits and beverages to meet with the increasing demand at her store. She is in her 3rd loan cycle with good repayment history. She is expecting boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salt, biscuits and beverages to meet the increasing demand at her store.

loans.name: Alex Antonio

texts.es: Alex, un humilde joven habitante del barrio laureles norte quien busca como salir adelante junto a su familia, su esposa se encarga del orden del hogar y cuida de sus pequeños hijos a quienes apoya con su labor vendiendo calzados desde hace 15 años, el cual es su único medio de ingresos, para mantenerlo con productos solicita el crédito, para invertir en variedades de calzado, para tener que ofrecer a las personas y garantizar el pan de cada día de sus hijos.
texts.en: Alex is  a humble young inhabitant from the Laureles Norte neighborhood who is looking for a way to get ahead in life along with his family. His wife is responsible for keeping the household in order and looking after their young children. Alex meanwhile supports them through his job selling shoes which he has been doing for 15 years and which is his only form of income. To keep having products on hand, Alex is seeking this loan to invest in a variety of shoes so that he has goods to offer customers and guarantee his children's daily bread.

loans.use: to buy a variety of shoes.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 63 years old, married and the father of eight children. For the last ten years, he has earned a living by selling farm produce in Mpeketoni, Lamu. He earns a monthly profit of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES).

Peter is applying for his third loan of 30,000 KES to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs needed for his business. He will use the profits made possible by this loan to pay school fees for his youngest child. His goal for the future is to venture into mixed farming with a view to increasing his income so as to improve his family's living standards.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs for his farming business

loans.name: Shamim

texts.en:
Ms Shamim, a 45-year-old married woman, has been selling bangles for about 10 years. Bangles are considered traditional accessories in a country such as Pakistan, where women use them for a traditional look on special occasions like Eid and weddings. Shamim sells beautiful bangles with various designs, especially those intended for bridal parties.

Shamim initiated her business with the support of Kashf Foundation. Taking a loan from Kashf helped her account for expenses she thought she could never bear. She is striving hard to meet her family expenditures, responsible as she is for providing good food, clothing, and education for her children.

Shamim is requesting her fourth loan of Rs. 40,000 to purchase stocks of colorful bangles in various designs and sizes. This will help in attracting more customers, and she hopes to have a good experience with this new loan as she dreams of expanding her business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of colorful bangles in various designs and sizes.

loans.name: Zeban

texts.en: Ms. Zeban is a 47-year-old married woman running a business of selling milk with her husband for 15 years. They have two buffaloes and three cows, and sell their milk to many of their neighbors, along with butter and cheese that they make from the milk. Zeban looks after the buffaloes and cows and performs the task of collecting milk from them while her husband sells it to different places on a daily basis. They are happily doing it together to support their family. They have 6 children, five of them are school-going. Zeban needs to earn much more to meet their everyday expenditures including food, clothing and education. In order to make huge profits, she requested a loan of 20,000 PKR to buy one more milk buffalo to cater more customers. Zeban hopes to have an increase in the production capacity of milk which ultimately helps in generating more cash.

loans.use: to buy one more milk buffalo

loans.name: Agartha

texts.en: Although she grew up in difficult circumstances, Agartha is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling towels, cloth, and sponges in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). She has been involved in this enterprise for 10 years. Agartha is a widow without any children. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her support herself and her extended family. Agartha wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of towels, cloth, and sponges. In the long term, Agartha plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels

loans.name: Yasmin

texts.en: Ms. Yasmin is a 53-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband in her home. She has gained 5 years of experience in this field.  Her husband also assists her by purchasing stock of goods from the market as he has maintained many contacts over the years. Yasmin is motivated to provide her family with good quality food, clothing and health. She wants to grow her business so she requested a loan of 35,000 PKR to buy packs of salts, biscuits and oil to meet the increasing demand at her store. She has been in association with Kashf Foundation for four years. She is expecting a boost in her earnings and dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy packs of salts, biscuits and oil to meet the increasing demand at her store.

loans.name: Komal

texts.en:
Ms. Komal is a 32-year-old, unmarried, vigorous lady. She has been running a business of hand embroidery for many years to contribute to the family income. Her embroidery patterns are very popular in her community. Due to increased demand for her embroidery designs, she is indulging other women in her business. She is motivated to provide her family with the basic necessities of life including food, clothes and education.

In order to meet the growing demand for her embroidery, she needs to engage some more women. She requested a loan of 40,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR) to buy reels of threads in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment. In this way, she will be able to cater to more customers consistently. She is hopeful to get an increase in her income by targeting more customers.

loans.use: to buy reels of threads in different colors and packs of beads, sequins and stones for embellishment.

loans.name: Fusena

texts.en: Even though Fusena grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Fusena is an entrepreneur. For a living, she prepares and sells ‘Wakye’ (a traditional Ghanaian dish made primarily from beans, rice and colored leaves). She primarily sells her ‘Wakye’ in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began 10 years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their child. Fusena has identified that there are growing demands among consumers for her ‘Wakye’. Nevertheless, she is unable to meet their needs due to a limited inventory capacity. Thus she aims to use her loan to purchase a greater quantity of rice and beans, therefore helping her to prepare more of her tasty ‘Wakye’. With the new profits from her expanded business, Fusena wants to buck the trend by ensuring that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of rice and beans, therefore helping her to prepare more of her tasty ‘Wakye’

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman with three children, the eldest being 10 and the youngest, 2. She describes herself as an honest mother who wants to give her children an improved living standard. 

Irene is applying for a loan of KES 20,000, which will be used to purchase more soap for packaging and reselling. This is her second successive loan with SMEP DTM. She has been operating this business for the past two years.

loans.use: to purchase more soap for packaging and reselling.

loans.name: Mercy A.

texts.en:
Even though Mercy grew up in poverty and without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. 

Currently, Mercy is an entrepreneur. She sells cloth in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began eight years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their four children. 

Mercy has identified that there are growing demands among customers for her product. Nevertheless, she is unable to meet their needs, due to limited inventory capacity. Thus, she aims to use her loan to purchase more cloth to sell. 

With the new profits from her expanded business, Mercy wants to buck the trend by ensuring that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth to sell.

loans.name: Segundo Luis

texts.es:
Luis con 39 años de edad, ha dedicado gran parte de su vida a la agricultura, actividad que aprendió de sus padres y abuelos. Enfocado en la producción de berenjena, ha sacado adelante a su esposa y dos hijos. Construyó su vivienda con gran esfuerzo y ahora les suministra educación a sus hijos con el fin de garantizarles un mejor futuro. 

Con el objetivo de comprar insumos (semillas, fertilizantes y adecuación de sistemas de riego para su cultivo) se encuentra solicitando un crédito, ya que no cuenta con los recursos para realizar dicha inversión, 
Espera incrementar su producción y mejorar la calidad de su familia.
texts.en:
Luis is 39 years old.  He has dedicated much of his life to agriculture, an activity he learned from his parents and grandparents.  He has supported his wife and two children growing eggplants.  He built his home with great effort and he is now providing his children with an education in order to guarantee them a better future.

Luis is requesting a loan to purchase materials (seeds, fertilizers) and to make repairs to irrigation systems for his crops, as he does not have the resources to make such an investment.  He hopes his production will improve so he can improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase materials (seeds, fertilizers) and make repairs to irrigation systems for his crop.

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: Doña Maria de 47 años de edad, vive en casa propia con su esposo y su hija, Maria es una madre de familia muy responsable y trabajadora, ha logrado sacar adelante a su familia. Ella posee una tienda de productos comestibles como pan, refrescos, aceites, golosinas y también de primera necesidad como: jabón y shampoo entre otras cosas tiene su negocio en su casa de habitación desde hace 19 años. Maria solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda surtir aún más la tienda con macarrones, acites, salsa de tomates, etc. de manera que pueda atender mejor a sus clientes y de esta misma forma mejorar sus ventas lo cual es su prioridad para sacar adelante su hogar.
texts.en:
Maria, 47, lives in her own home with her husband and their daughter, Maria is a very responsible and hardworking mother, she has suceeded in getting her family ahead in life. She owns a grocery store with goods such as bread, fizzy drinks, oil, sweets and other basic items such as soap and shampoo amongst others. She has been running her business from her home for the last 19 years.

Maria is seeking a loan to increase the stock of macaroni, oils, tomato sauces and so on in the store, which means she can serve her customers even better and therein improve her sales which is her priority to get the household ahead.

loans.use: to buy oil, macaroni, tomato sauces and so on.

loans.name: Zarifjon

texts.ru: Зарифчону 39 лет. Он очень добросовестный человек. Он женат, и на воспитании имеет 2 детей. Его жена учительница в средней школе, а дети еще не трудоспособные. Они ходят в среднюю школу. Зарифчон более 8 лет занимается услугой мастера по стройки домов и других объектов. Он очень хороший семьянин и старается, чтобы его семья жила в достатке. Он планирует построить новый дом для его семьи. Однако его доход не позволяет ему начать стройку. Он планирует построить дом по новой и современной планировке, чтобы были все условия. Его жена хочет большую и светлую кухню, а дети просят его сделать для них детскую с яркими обоями. Он запрашивает займ на сумму 8000 сомони для покупки строительный материалов, как цемент, древесина и т.п. Он ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en:
Zarifjon is 39 years old. He is a very conscientious man. He is married and raising two children. His wife is a teacher at a secondary school, and his children are not yet of working age. They go to secondary school. 

Zarifjon has worked with construction services for more than 8 years, building houses and other objects. He is a very good family man and works hard for his family to live in abundance. He plans to build a new house for his family, however, his income does not allow him to start building. He plans to build a house with a new and modern layout, which has all services. His wife would like a large and bright kitchen, and the children have asked him to make a children's room with colorful wallpaper. 

Zarifjon requests a loan in the amount of 8,000 somoni for the purchase of building materials, such as cement, wood and so on. He awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy building materials, such as cement and wood, to build a new house

loans.name: Santusa

texts.es:
Santusa se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno para la producción de leche la cual vende al por menor en su comunidad, también se dedica a la agricultura y floricultura ya que en ese sector el clima es benigno y apto para ello. Su casa está ubicada en la comunidad de rio abajo, del Sector Mecapaca de La provincia Murillo del Departamento de La Paz a una hora y media  de distancia  de la ciudad de La Paz; cuenta con  algunas cabezas de ganado  y sembradíos de flores y verduras.

El crédito lo requiere para comprar forraje  para su ganado y así mejorar su producción lechera.

El sueño de Santusa  es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado, precautelando la buena salud de ellos.

Es la tercera  vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la segunda  vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Santusa works raising cattle for milk production, which she then sells in her community. She also works in agriculture and floriculture as in this region the weather is benign and perfect for such activity. Her house is located in the Rio Abajo community, in the Mecapaca Sector of the province of Murilla, in the Department of La Paz. This is about an hour and a half from the city of La Paz. She currently owns a few head of cattle and crops of vegetables and flowers. 

She needs this loan in order to purchase  feed for her cattle and thereby improve her milk production. Santusa's goal is to increase the number of cattle she owns, thereby safeguarding the strength of her herd. This is her third loan through IMPRO, and her second loan through Kiva.

loans.use: purchase feed for her dairy cow.

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Faustina did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Faustina sells charcoal in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). She has been doing so for about 10 years. She is married to a farmer, and together they have 6 children. Faustina uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. Faustina will use the loan to purchase more charcoal, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Faustina wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: Ms. Parveen is a 34-year-old married woman and a mother of six children. She is motivated to provide for her family.  Four months ago, she started her own general store in her community. Her son also assists her by dealing with customers at her store. She offers various goods for daily use. She has good communication skills and counts on a good client list. To meet the demands of her customers without fail she needs to purchase more rice, flour and sugar. So she applied for a loan of Rs. 30,000. She is in her 3rd loan cycle and thankful for the tremendous support. She expects increased earnings and wishes to utilize part of her revenues to deal with personal expenses and to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to purchase rice, flour and sugar to sell

loans.name: Ghulam-Kubra

texts.en: Ms. Ghulam-Kubra had a difficult time after her husband's business failure. She decided to work with her husband to support her family for a better future. Two years ago she began seamstress work in her house. She sews for the people living around her house and uses the income to support her entire family. However, due to lack of availability of funds she is unable to meet the daily demands of her customers. She has three children; she is striving hard to meet their demands including food, clothing, and health. Currently she in her 2nd loan cycle and applied for a loan of Rs 30,000 from Kashf. She intends to use this loan to buy raw material including cloth, threads in different colors with packs of laces and zippers to create a means of increasing revenues so she may be able to generate a healthier source of income.

loans.use: to buy raw material including cloth, threads in different colors with packs of laces and zippers.

loans.name: Santusa

texts.es:
Santusa se dedica a la crianza de ganado vacuno para la producción de leche la cual vende al por menor en su comunidad, también se dedica a la agricultura y floricultura ya que en ese sector el clima es benigno y apto para ello. Su casa está ubicada en la comunidad de rio abajo, del Sector Mecapaca del Departamento de La Paz a una hora y media  de distancia  de la ciudad de La Paz. 
.
El crédito lo solicita para comprar forraje para sus vacas lecheras y semilla mejorada la cual pueda rendir en mayor proporción y mejor calidad de  su producción de productos agrícolas .

El sueño de Santusa  es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado e incrementar sus productos agrícolas.
Es la tercera  vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la primera  vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Santusa works raising cattle for milk production, which she then sells in her community. She also works in agriculture and floriculture as in this region the weather is mild and perfect for such activity. Her house is located in the Rio Abajo community, in the Mecapaca Sector of the province of Murilla, in the Department of La Paz. This is about an hour and a half from the city of La Paz.

She is applying for this loan in order to purchase feed for her dairy cattle and better seed which will improve the quality and quantity of her production of agricultural products. Santusa's goal is to increase the number of cattle she owns and increase her agricultural production. This is her third loan through IMPRO, and her second loan through Kiva.

loans.use: purchase feed for her dairy cattle and better seed for her production of agricultural products.

loans.name: Virgencita De Guadalupe Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “VIRGENCITA DE GUADALUPE”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.                                                                                                                                                                                             

La socia es la Sra. Juliana ella es casada y tiene 47 años y tiene 2 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes como arroz, azúcar, leche, galletas y aceite, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 6 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar arroz, azúcar, leche y aceite.
 Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de venta de animales, negocio de venta de maíz, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de comida.

 
La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members belong to the “Virgencita de Guadalupe”communal bank which is located in the district of Urubamba, belonging to the province of Urubamba and the department of Cusco.

The member in question is Juliana, who is married, 47 years old, and has two children. Juliana works in her grocery store business with goods such as rice, sugar, milk, biscuits and oil. She works from 8:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m, and has already six years of experience in this sector and it is going very well. 

Juliana dreams of expanding the grocery store. She is seeking this loan to buy rice, sugar, milk and oil. 

The other members make their living in sales, selling livestock, corn, grocery store business and a foodstall.

Juliana thanks those who help her to realize this dream, via this means, and pledges to meet her repayments in the set timeframe.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk and oil.

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame   Salimata  âgée de 39 ans, mariée et  sans  enfant. Elle vit  avec  son mari au quartier Angoulême  de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté  l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt à faire les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui vendait des habits. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à son coté, elle
Décide d’évoluer seule pour mener la même activité que cette dernière. Elle a une expérience de 10 ans dans ce secteur, elle a un grand réseau de clientèle composée majoritairement des détaillants. Sa boutique se trouve au marché Château prés des vendeurs de légumes, l’accès de sa boutique est facile. Sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses habits qui sont des importations venus du Togo, du Burkina et du Nigeria mais également à son prix abordable.
 Dans le dessein  d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a  fait recours  à Soro Yiriwaso.  Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 48  mois, après   4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts  individuels bien  remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter ,5 balles de pagnes wax,  elle s’approvisionne généralement au  Nigeria.  
Madame    Salimata  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes, avec ce prêt  elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 100 000 FCFA. Ce dernier lui permettra  de  rembourser  son prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso et d’augmenter son fonds de  commerce.
texts.en:
Salimata is 39 years old, married and has no children. She lives with her husband in the Angoulême district of Ségou (the Republic of Mali's fourth administrative region).

Salimata did not attend school for social reasons and thus at an early age started income-generating activities with her mother who sold clothes. After several years' apprenticeship at her mother's side she decided to build up a similar business by herself. She now has ten years' experience in this field and has a large network of customers, made up principally of retailers. Her shop is in the Château market near to the vegetable sellers, and access to the shop is easy. The strength of her sales is due to the quality of her clothing which is imported from Togo, Burkina and Nigeria, and also to her affordable prices. 

With a view to increasing her capital so that she can meet customer demand, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso and has had a relationship with the institution for the past 48 months. Having had four group loans and two individual loans, she is now on her third individual loan with which she is planning to buy five bundles of  "pagnes wax" (highly decorative and colourful pieces of fabric). She generally gets her supplies from Nigeria.

Salimata sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up mainly of women, and with this loan she is expecting to make a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA. This will enable her to repay her loan to Soro Yiriwaso and increase her capital.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Francia Jazmin

texts.es:
La clienta Francia vive en Guayaquil. Ella empezó su negocio de confeccion de ropa por tener más ingresos y asi ayudar en los gastos de su casa. Trabaja sola, el tipo de negocio que ella tiene es de confecciones de ropa.

El problema que ella tiene en su negocio es que no tiene las maquinas suficientes para hacer todas las confecciones que le piden. Ella tiene unión libre su pareja trabaja en albañil, tiene 3 hijos de 2 años 3 años y 5 años estudia en escuela fiscal el mayor.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar tela y maquinas. Su sueño  es que sus hijos crezcan con la bendición de Dios y que sean trabajadores.
texts.en:
Francia lives in Guayaquil. She started her sewing business so that she could have more income to help with the household expenses. Francia works alone in her business of making clothes.

The problem she faces in her business is not having enough machines for all of the sewing jobs that are submitted to her. She is in a common-law relationship with her partner, who works as a bricklayer. Francia has three children (ages 2, 3, and 5). The oldest child attends a state school.

With this loan, she will buy fabrics and machines. Her dream is for her children to grow up with God’s blessing and become workers.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and machines.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for English lessons.

loans.name: Ashra

texts.en:
Ms. Ashra is a 40-year-old married woman and has been running a business of sewing clothes for the last eight years. She has four children; among them, three go to school for getting primary and middle level education. 

Her husband does not have a permanent job. Therefore, Ashra started her own business to help her family to fulfill basic needs of life like food, house rent, and education. Over time, she has maintained regular contacts with boutiques and earns enough income to contribute to the family’s income. 

At this time, Ashra wants to purchase a new sewing machine for her daughter, who will help her in completing orders on time. For this reason, she applied to Kashf Foundation for a loan of Rs. 20,000.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine for her daughter, who will help her in completing orders on time.

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en: Due to difficult circumstances, Ernestina did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Ernestina sells charcoal in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). She has been doing so for about 4 years. She is married to a farmer, and together they have 5 children. Ernestina uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. Ernestina will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of charcoal, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Ernestina wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of charcoal.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina is a widow and has 4 children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Augustina is a successful businesswoman. She sells clothing in Asebu Ekrokul (near Cape Coast). She has been actively involved in this business for about 2 years.

As the sole breadwinner in the family, Augustina uses her income to provide for the entire family. Augustina will use the loan to purchase more clothing to help improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Augustina plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for sale

loans.name: Ani Lizzeth

texts.es: Ani, tiene 42 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene dos hijos, vive en una aldea de Azacualpa, Santa Bárbara.
